bug:
If you've found a bug I'm sure Steve would love to fix it as soon as possible. There's a currently two ways we'd prefer you doing this.
**Prefered way:**
 Using github helps Steve track bugs easier, and increases the chance that something gets fixed.
<https://github.com/steveseguin/vdo.ninja/issues>

**Alternative way:**
If you don't have a github account, or want to make one you can head over to #bug-report and write your report.
**Please remember to include the following:**
**1.** What happened?
**2.** What did you expect to happen?
**3.** What steps do you take to re-produce the bug?
**4.** What's your *operating system*?
**5.** What *software/browser* are you using?
**6.** Which branch of VDO.Ninja did it happen on?

 **Thanks for your contribution**
cache:
Sometimes browser cache can become troublesome, especially when new releases come out.
Force reload your browser to clear site cache.

Chrome / Firefox on windows
	CTRL + ⇧ + R
	CTRL + F5
Chrome / Firefox on macOS
	⇧ + reload button
	⌘ + ⇧ + R
common:
Here's a compiled list of some of the most **common issues:**
<https://docs.vdo.ninja/common-errors-and-known-issues>
Look through them and see if there's a way you can fix the issue you're having!
contact: If you want to contact Steve, he can usually be found on Discord throughout the day. If you have a private matter and need support he is also available on email at **steve@seguin.email**
cpu:
Encoding: Currently VDO.Ninja doesn't hardware encode most outgoing streams. Exceptions are some mobile devices and laptops that can offload H.264 encode from the CPU.
Decoding: If everything is OK, your GPU should decode incoming VDO.Ninja streams.

https://docs.vdo.ninja/getting-started/sponsor
docs: You can find the full VDO.ninja documentation here: <https://docs.vdo.ninja/>
electron:
The Electron Capture app is a frameless browser designed specifically for VDO.Ninja users. It is more stable than OBS Browser Source, it can be pinned, and it can output audio to a Virtual Audio cable.
You can window-capture the app to bring VDO.Ninja video into OBS or Zoom, and multiple Electron Capture windows can be opened via batch script.
https://github.com/steveseguin/electroncapture/releases
faq:
Before you ask a question about what VDO.Ninja is or how it works, please make sure it isn't already answered on the FAQ page! https://docs.vdo.ninja/faq
**Thank you!**
firefox: **Firefox** isn't officially supported. If it works, then great! But for support please use **Chrome** for windows. If you find major issues with Firefox feel to report but them but please *do not* expect them to get fixed immediately.
github: **VDO.Ninja's** source code is hosted at <https://github.com/steveseguin/vdo.ninja> and is open to community development. Feel free to submit a PR for small code contributions or get in-touch for greater involvement. While you are welcome to fork the repo, we will not support older code while we are still in a phase of early rapid-development.
hwaccel: Check your Hardware Acceleration status for browser sources: https://i.imgur.com/z8WoME1.png
iphone: The iPhone's h264 hardware encoder can only do 720p30. Beyond that it's not compatible. If you want 1080p, on compatible/newer iOS devices, you can use the &codec=vp8 to get 1080p capture -- however a older iPhone like a 6S, might not be realistic as it will use the CPU to encode... and an iPhone 6S might struggle there. iPhones don't handle large group rooms that well, especially older iPhones. iPhone is limited to 3 h264 streams
latest:
Check out the over-all changes for the **latest version of VDO.Ninja:**
https://docs.vdo.ninja/releases
limit: There is no self imposed limit on the number of VDO.Ninja guests able to enter a room. It's up for you to decide how many people your system can handle. Remember that VDO.Ninja is a peer to peer n-to-n connection. Meaning if you have 5 people in a room, all 5 people will be connecting to other 4. This can severely limit your options, since every connection is a new encoding load. There are ways to optimize CPU usage by reducing total room bitrate, or outputting only the OBS feed into a room, and feeding that to all guests. Check !advanced for more info.
macos: Please update OBS to at least v26.1.2. This release has a very important couple of fixes that makes using VDO.Ninja in macOS possible. Download: https://github.com/obsproject/obs-studio/releases/latest
updates:
Check out the over-all changes for the **latest version of VDO.Ninja:**
https://docs.vdo.ninja/releases
packetloss:
High packet loss can result in low-quality streams; it's commonly caused by WiFi usage, but it may also be due webRTC-blocking or poor network routing.
Switching to Ethernet from WiFI or changing browsers may help.

See https://docs.vdo.ninja/common-errors-and-known-issues/packet-loss for updated details on more solutions. There's also an older YouTube about it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=je2ljlvLzlY
permanent: For information on permanent links, please see: https://docs.vdo.ninja/common-errors-and-known-issues/how-to-get-permanent-links

s: If you need help, support or have feedback regarding one of the Ninja products, please use <#746573900715917334>, <#877898730240634920>, <#792425204793606186> or <#701496038166495343> respectively!
software: The technologies used in the creation of VDO.Ninja are application agnostic. It doesn’t know how the output URL is being used. To that end, any software that can use a browser based source should be capable of using the output URL provided by vdo.ninja. However, VDO.Ninja is only officially tested using OBS (obsproject.com), and functionality developed to address the needs of that user base.
speedtest:
You can check your vdo.ninja performance here: <https://vdo.ninja/speedtest>
This will send your video/ audio feed to VDO.Ninja's server and back. It is then possible to check for some metrics like bitrate, packet loss or buffer.

streamdeck:
To control VDO.Ninja with your Elgato Stream Deck you can use [MIDI](https://docs.vdo.ninja/advanced-settings/api-and-midi-parameters/midi#elgato-streamdeck-support) or the [HTTP/Websocket API](https://docs.vdo.ninja/advanced-settings/api-and-midi-parameters/api).
The [Bitfocus Companion](https://github.com/bitfocus/companion-module-vdo-ninja) implements the HTTP/Websocket API.
support: If you need help please use the appropriate channel: <#746573900715917334>, <#877898730240634920>, <#878774894555447306>. Please make sure you provide as much detail as possible to your issue and circumstances and be patient if you don't receive an answer right away!
supported:
**Supported browsers/OS:**
Chrome Windows
Chrome Android
Chrome MacOS
Safari iOS
Chromium Linux
**Not officially supported browsers/OS:**
Firefox Windows
Safari MacOS
**Note:** Just because something isn't supported doesn't mean it won't work - just don't expect bug fixes or compatibility.
test: testing testing 1 2 3, is this thing on?
voicemeeter: On windows Voicemeeter might help you solve some more advanced audio routing challenges <https://vb-audio.com/Voicemeeter/>
wifi:
If at all possible, switch to ethernet.
- you can try &buffer=200 on the view links to mitigate issues
- If Packet Loss is hurting your stream (test at !speedtest), try using Speedify - <https://speedify.com>. It can help, especially if you can bond WiFi with LTE. (Redundant / bonded mode)
- Try adding '&privacy' to your URL which might reduce packet loss.
- Physically move closer to your router.
- Don't have more clients on the network; put others on LTE if you must be on WiFi
- If you can, don't be on battery, connect your device.
- Don't expect flawless high resolution, high bitrate feeds. Reduce your requirements. Try 720p or even lower.
- Consider limiting FPS
- VP9 or H264 works better than VP8 within OBS
- Avoid bluetooth.
- Be ready to 'reconnect' failed audio connections/tracks
- Close all other non essential apps
